awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Investigation of Material Removal in Impact Machining by Loose Abrasives
awd_abstract_narration:
Existing nanomachining processes that rely on lithographic and energy beam based methods often need cleanroom environments and huge capital investments. Their shortcomings include limited choice of work materials, chemical hazards, and thermally induced defects on machined surfaces. This award supports a study of material removal in brittle materials by the impact of nano diamond particles. Research results can lead to a low cost alternative for nanomachining at room temperature without the shortcomings of existing nanomachining processes. The new process can improve the nanomachinability of a wide variety of both conductive and nonconductive materials, and may have applications in biomedical, electronic, automotive, energy, and metal working industries. Potential applications in these industries include nanostructured scaffolds for artificial tissue engineering, nanostructured switches and wireless transmitters, ultra-low friction layers for thermal barrier coatings, and nanostructured proton exchange membranes for fuel cells. 
 
The experimental platform for the new process is an atomic force microscope where workpiece is vibrated at the frequency of 20-160 kHz. Machining is achieved by the impact of loose nano diamond particles in liquid medium. The research objective is to understand effects of kinetic energy on material removal mechanism (plastic deformation or brittle fracture). The level of kinetic energy is determined by machining conditions (primarily diamond particle size and vibration frequency). The research plan consists of computer simulations and experimental studies. Extended finite element methods will be used to simulate the machining process. In these models, to mimic the impact given by the diamond particle on the workpiece at different kinetic energy levels, the workpiece is fixed and the diamond particle is treated as a vibrating rigid body (at the frequency of 20-160 kHz). Drucker-Prager constitutive law will be employed to describe the behavior of brittle materials. Finite element models will be validated by comparing model predictions with experimental results. Machining experiments using graphene, silicon, and glass samples will be performed at different levels of kinetic energy by varying the mean size of diamond particles (5, 10, 15 nm) and vibrating the workpiece at different frequencies in the range of 20-160 kHz. Machined surfaces will be examined using electron microscopy, and optical microscope to determine if the material removal is done by plastic deformation or brittle fracture.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this collaborative project between University of Cincinnati (UC) and Saint Louis University (SLU) was to study the mechanism(s) of material removal in the newly developed Vibration Assisted Nano Impact machining by Loose Abrasives (VANILA) process, wherein brittle materials are machined by the impact of nanodiamonds. The research objective was to understand the effects of kinetic energy on the material removal mechanism (plastic deformation or brittle fracture). Specifically, the effects of the impact speed, which is associated with a vibration frequency of the AFM tip, impact angle, friction coefficient between nanoparticles and the workpiece, and operating temperature were investigated in this research by simulation and experimentation.

Simulation studies performed at SLU by Finite Element Method using the commercial software package ABAQUS revealed hydrostatic pressure over 25 GPa on silicon during the VANILA machining process. Since this is significantly higher than the hardness of silicon (14 GPa), this observation suggests the possibility of ductile mode machining of silicon in VANILA. Also, the phase transformation was noticed when the impact-induced hydrostatic pressure in the contact area changed. Impact speed was found to have the most dominating effect on the phase transformation process, followed by the impact angle and friction coefficient. 

An inhouse built experimental system shown in Figure 1 was built at UC. VANILA experiments using a Tungsten tool and a slurry made of nanodiamond grains of 10 nm size were performed on a silicon workpiece vibrated at frequencies in the range of 6-12 kHz. A control system capable of coarse approach, piezo positioning, integral-feedback scanning, and sample vibration was assembled at UC (Figure 2) using in-house built circuitry, a commercially-available piezo amplifier, and working parts. This hardware was operated by an in-house made Graphic user interface (GUI) programmed in MATLAB. Fundamental routines including coarse approach and imaging were executed.  The integral feedback circuitry built for imaging is shown in Figure 3. Holes having diameters in the range of 200 nm-1.6 μm as shown in Figure 4 were successfully machined.

The absence of random cracks on the SEM images of the experimental results supports the predictions made by the simulation about the feasibility of ductile regime machining (DRM) of brittle material during the VANILA machining process. To gain a fundamental understanding of the effect of liquid medium on the material removal behavior during the VANILA process, Molecular Dynamics Simulation (MDS) based study was conducted under different initial conditions with and without the presence of liquid medium (water). The MDS results showed that while the water absorbs some energy from the abrasive grain, it also provides a lubricating layer to the grain preventing adhesion on the workpiece surface. Visualizations of the atomic configurations of the workpiece showed that the presence of water molecules could significantly affect the material dislocations during the impact process.

At UC, two graduate students (one female), and thirteen undergraduates (including 4 females) have been trained by the PI (Murali Sundaram) on molecular dynamics simulation, and experimentation.  Sai Vamshi is planning to defend his MS thesis in Spring 2020. Ms. Anne Brant is using part of the experimental system built in this project for her Ph.D. studies. The outcome of this project is being used for curriculum development to educate graduate and undergraduate students in "Micro and Nanomanufacturing"- a dual-level course and "Advanced Manufacturing processes" a graduate course taught by Prof. Sundaram at the University of Cincinnati (UC). The results of this research are being disseminated through peer-reviewed publications, presentations, university websites, and reports to NSF.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2019
Modified by: Murali Sundaram
